writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey had grown accustomed to the hum of fluorescent lights overhead, the sterile scent of the FBI office, and the faint aroma of freshly brewed coffee wafting from the break room. It was a far cry from the world he used to inhabit – the world of high-stakes art forgeries, lavish parties, and high-end galleries. But it was home now. Or so he told himself.

As he walked into the conference room, he was greeted by the familiar faces of his new colleagues: Peter, Diana, and Sara. They were all chatting and laughing, but their smiles faltered as they noticed his arrival. It was a subtle change, but one that Neal had grown accustomed to over the past year. They didn't trust him yet. And who could blame them?

Just as Neal was about to take a seat, the door swung open and his old partner, Mozzie, strode in. Mozzie's eyes sparkled with a familiar glint, one that Neal knew all too well. It was the look of a man with a plan, and a plan that was about to change everything.

"Neal, my old friend," Mozzie said, his voice dripping with charm. "It's been too long."

Neal's instincts kicked in, and he felt a familiar tension rise up his spine. He knew that look, that tone. Mozzie was up to something, and it was probably not good.

"What can I do for you, Mozzie?" Neal asked, trying to keep his tone neutral.

Mozzie flashed a quick smile. "I've got a job for you, Neal. A little heist. Nothing too complicated, just a high-end art piece that's been sitting in a private collection for years. It's the perfect score."

Neal's gut told him to walk away, to tell Mozzie that he was no longer interested in his old life. But something about Mozzie's words stuck with him. The thrill of the job, the rush of adrenaline, it was all too familiar.

"I'm not interested, Mozzie," Neal said finally, trying to sound firm.

Mozzie's expression changed, and for a moment, Neal saw a glimmer of disappointment. But it was quickly replaced by a calculating look. "Come on, Neal. You're not still stuck on that 'FBI consultant' nonsense, are you?"

Neal felt a surge of defensiveness, but he pushed it down. He knew that Mozzie was trying to push his buttons, to get under his skin. But he also knew that he had to stay focused.

"I am a consultant, Mozzie. And I'm not going to help you with this heist."

Mozzie raised an eyebrow. "You're really committed to this whole 'good guy' thing, aren't you?"

Neal felt a pang of guilt, but he pushed it aside. He knew that he was still a work in progress, that he was still finding his way in this new life.

"I'm trying to be, Mozzie. And I'm not going to let you undermine that."

Mozzie's smile returned, but this time it was tinged with a hint of sadness. "I knew you'd say that, Neal. But I had to try."

As Mozzie turned to leave, Neal felt a sense of relief wash over him. He had made the right decision, hadn't he? Or was he just fooling himself?

He looked around the conference room, at the faces of his new colleagues. They were all watching him, waiting for him to make a move. And for a moment, Neal wondered if he was truly ready to leave his old life behind.

But as he looked at Mozzie's retreating back, he knew that he had made the right choice. He was a master art forger turned FBI consultant, and he was determined to make it work.

"I'm sorry, Mozzie," Neal said finally, his voice barely above a whisper.

Mozzie turned back, his eyes sparkling with a hint of mischief. "Don't be sorry, Neal. Just be you."

As the door closed behind Mozzie, Neal felt a sense of peace wash over him. He was still a work in progress, but he was getting there. And with his new colleagues by his side, he knew that he could face whatever came next.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
The bar was dimly lit, a small, unassuming place that seemed to exist solely for the locals. Dean Winchester slid onto the stool beside Crowley, a hint of a smile playing on his lips.

"Long time no see, Peaches," Dean said, his eyes crinkling at the corners.

Crowley raised an eyebrow, a small, wry smile twisting his lips. "And you've only just now realized that, have you?" He signaled the bartender for a drink, his eyes never leaving Dean's face.

They sat in silence for a moment, the only sound the gentle hum of the bar and the occasional murmur of conversation from the patrons. Dean's eyes never left Crowley's face, and Crowley's gaze drifted over Dean's features, taking in the sharp jawline, the piercing blue eyes.

It had been years since they'd last spoken, years since Crowley had last seen Dean. He'd thought of him often, of course – who wouldn't? Dean Winchester was one of the few people who'd ever managed to see past Crowley's façade, to understand the depths beneath.

But it was a complicated thing, their history. Crowley had been working to build an empire, to solidify his hold on the supernatural world. Dean, on the other hand, had been on a mission to save the world, one demon at a time.

And then, of course, there was the matter of their respective moral compasses. Crowley's was a little... flexible, shall we say. Dean's, on the other hand, was a bit more... pointed.

But as they sat there, the tension between them was palpable. It was a tension that had nothing to do with their respective moral compasses, and everything to do with the spark that had always flown between them.

"So," Dean said, breaking the silence, "what brings you here?"

Crowley shrugged, a small, wry smile twisting his lips. "Just enjoying the atmosphere, I suppose. And maybe, just maybe, running into old friends."

Dean's eyes locked onto Crowley's, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "I think you're running from something, Peaches," he said, his voice low and smooth.

Crowley's eyes flickered, a hint of surprise crossing his face. "And I think you're just trying to get under my skin," he retorted, a wry smile twisting his lips.

The banter went back and forth, a dance of words and wit that left both of them breathless. It was a conversation that could have gone on for hours, that could have continued indefinitely.

But eventually, Crowley's gaze drifted back to Dean's face, and he felt a pang in his chest. It was a pang that had nothing to do with the whiskey he'd been drinking, and everything to do with the man sitting beside him.

"I suppose I should get going," Crowley said, his voice low and smooth.

Dean's eyes locked onto his, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "I think you should," he said, his voice low and husky.

Crowley's heart skipped a beat as Dean reached out, his fingers brushing against Crowley's. It was a fleeting touch, but it sent shivers down Crowley's spine.

"I'll walk you out," Dean said, his eyes locked onto Crowley's face.

Crowley nodded, a small, wry smile twisting his lips. "I'd like that," he said, his voice low and smooth.

As they walked out of the bar, the night air was cool and crisp, a perfect contrast to the tension that had been building between them. Crowley felt a sense of excitement, a sense of possibility that he hadn't felt in years.

And as they stood outside, the only sound the distant hum of the city, Crowley realized that maybe, just maybe, he was ready to rewrite his plan.

Maybe, just maybe, he was ready to take a chance on love.

The days that followed were a whirlwind of activity, a blur of federal agents and family barbecues. Crowley found himself caught up in Dean's world, a world that was chaotic and unpredictable, but also full of life and laughter.

It was a world that Crowley had never known before, a world that was full of possibility and promise. And as he stood beside Dean, his hand clasped in Dean's, Crowley knew that he was exactly where he was meant to be.

The future was uncertain, of course. There would be federal agents and family barbecues, and who knew what else. But as Crowley looked into Dean's eyes, he knew that he was ready for whatever came next.

Because when it came down to it, some things were worth rewriting the plan for.

And as they stood there, the sun setting over the city, Crowley knew that he'd found his happily ever after.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey had always been a master of bending the rules, of finding loopholes and exploiting weaknesses in the system. It was what had made him a successful con artist, after all. But since being caught and released into FBI custody as a consultant, he'd had to adapt to a whole new set of rules – the ones that dictated how an FBI agent was supposed to behave.

Peter Burke, his handler, was a by-the-book kind of guy, always harping on about procedure and protocol. Neal had initially rolled his eyes at Peter's strict adherence to the rules, but over time, he'd come to appreciate the sense of order and structure that came with it.

Today, however, Neal found himself defending those very same rules during a heated case discussion with Peter.

"It's not about being 'too good to be true'," Neal said, his voice rising as he argued with Peter in front of their colleagues. "It's about being too good to be caught. And if we're going to catch these guys, we need to play by the rules."

Peter raised an eyebrow, clearly amused by Neal's sudden defense of proper procedures. "Oh, come on, Neal. You're not exactly known for your love of rules."

Neal shot him a wry smile. "Hey, I'm learning. And besides, it's not just about following the rules – it's about doing what's right."

The team around them seemed to be enjoying the exchange, and Neal couldn't blame them. It was a rare sight to see him defending the very things he used to mock.

But Peter just chuckled and shook his head. "You're a con artist, Neal. It's in your blood. I'm not sure even you believe what you're saying."

Neal's eyes narrowed, but he didn't rise to the bait. Instead, he took a deep breath and continued his argument, laying out a series of logical points that left Peter looking impressed.

As the discussion drew to a close, Neal felt a sense of pride and accomplishment. He'd never thought he'd be the kind of guy to defend proper procedures, but it seemed he was learning to appreciate the value of doing things by the book.

Peter, however, just grinned at him and said, "You know, Neal, I never thought I'd see the day where you'd be defending the rules. But I have to say, it's kind of sweet."

Neal rolled his eyes good-naturedly. "Shut up, Peter."

But as they left the conference room, Neal couldn't help but feel a sense of pride. Maybe, just maybe, he was starting to grow up.

The rest of the day passed in a blur of meetings and paperwork, but Neal's mind kept wandering back to the case they were working on – a complex Ponzi scheme that seemed to have no end in sight.

As he sat at his desk, going over the evidence, he couldn't help but think about the rules he'd been defending earlier. It was easy to get caught up in the excitement of the chase, of the thrill of the con. But at the end of the day, it was about doing what was right – and following the rules was a big part of that.

Peter poked his head into Neal's office, a look of amusement on his face. "Hey, Neal. I heard you're a convert to the Church of Proper Procedures now."

Neal looked up, a hint of a smile on his face. "Shut up, Peter."

But deep down, he knew Peter was right. He was changing, slowly but surely. And it felt good.

As the sun began to set over the city, Neal leaned back in his chair and closed his eyes, feeling a sense of peace wash over him. He knew he still had a long way to go, but for the first time in a long time, he felt like he was heading in the right direction.

And that, he thought, was a very good thing indeed.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
Captain Kirk's voice was laced with frustration as he spoke to Chief Engineer Montgomery Scott over the comms system. "Bones, we need to get this ship up and running, now. We can't just sit here in the middle of nowhere with no power and no communication."

Scotty's face was a picture of concentration as he worked on the console in front of him. "Aye, Captain. I'm tryin' me best, but I cannae find anythin' out of the ordinary. No signs of sabotage, no malfunctions... it's as if the ship just... stopped."

Kirk's eyes narrowed. "Scotty, we need to find out what's going on here. Run diagnostics, check the systems, see if there's anything that's not functioning properly."

Scotty nodded, his fingers flying across the console as he worked. "Aye, Captain. I'm runnin' a full diagnostic now. But I'm tellin' ye, I've never seen anything like this. It's as if the ship's just... given up."

The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the steady beeps of the ship's systems and the soft hum of the life support.

"Scotty," Kirk said finally, his voice low and urgent. "We need to think outside the box here. What if it's not just a technical failure? What if there's something else at play here?"

Scotty's eyes snapped up, a glint of understanding in them. "You mean, like a... a philosophical failure, Captain?"

Kirk's eyes narrowed. "Exactly. What if the ship's not just a collection of wires and circuits, but a living, breathing entity that's got its own... sense of self?"

Scotty's face was a picture of skepticism, but Kirk could see the wheels turning in his mind. "I see what ye mean, Captain. But how do we fix it, then?"

Kirk's smile was grim. "That's what we need to figure out, Scotty. But first, we need to talk to the rest of the crew. See if anyone's noticed anything... unusual."

As the two of them made their way to the bridge, Kirk couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. Something was off, and he couldn't quite put his finger on it. But he knew one thing for sure - they couldn't just sit here and wait for something to happen. They needed to take action, and fast.

The rest of the crew was gathered on the bridge, their faces pale and worried. Kirk's eyes met Scotty's, and he could see the same sense of determination in his friend's eyes.

"Alright, people," Kirk said, his voice firm. "We need to think this through. Scotty, what do you make of it all?"

Scotty's face was a picture of concentration as he spoke. "I've run diagnostics, Captain. I've checked the systems, the engines... everything. And I've come to one conclusion - this ship's not just malfunctioning, it's... it's in a state of suspended animation."

The crew's eyes widened in shock, and Kirk felt a shiver run down his spine. "What do you mean, Scotty?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper.

Scotty's eyes locked onto his. "I mean, Captain, that the ship's... it's not just a machine. It's a living, breathing entity that's... that's asleep."

The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the steady beeps of the ship's systems and the soft hum of the life support.

Kirk's eyes met Scotty's, and he could see the same sense of wonder in his friend's eyes. "Scotty, I think you might be onto something there."

As the two of them worked together to try and revive the ship, Kirk couldn't help but feel a sense of awe at the mysteries of the universe. And he knew one thing for sure - they were in this together, as a crew, and as a ship.

The clock was ticking down, and they had to act fast. But as they worked, Kirk couldn't help but feel a sense of hope. Maybe, just maybe, they could find a way to revive the ship, and get back on course.

And as they worked, the ship's systems began to stir, the lights flickering back to life, the engines humming once more.

The crew's cheers erupted through the ship, and Kirk's eyes met Scotty's, a grin spreading across his face. "Well done, Scotty," he said, his voice full of pride. "You've done it again."

Scotty's face was flushed with excitement as he turned to Kirk. "Aye, Captain. We make a good team, don't we?"

Kirk's smile was warm. "We do, Scotty. We do indeed."

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal watched with growing unease as Agent Thompson set up her makeshift desk in the corner of the office. The air was thick with tension, and not just because of the inevitable scrutiny that came with an audit. This was different. This was personal.

Thompson's eyes narrowed as she scanned the room, her gaze lingering on Neal. He could almost see the wheels turning in her head, piecing together the fragments of information she'd gathered so far. And none of it was good.

"What's the holdup, Thompson?" Peter asked, his voice even but firm.

"Just going over some discrepancies," she replied, her tone dripping with skepticism. "Seems like our Mr. Caffrey here has been... shall we say, 'creative' with his accounting records."

Neal's eyes flashed with anger, but he kept his cool. He'd been down this road before, and he knew the drill. Play along, gather information, and wait for the perfect moment to strike.

"Agent Thompson, I assure you, I'm as baffled as you are," he said, his voice smooth as silk. "I've done nothing but help this team since I arrived."

Thompson's gaze never wavered. "Save it, Caffrey. I've seen your work. You're a master forger. It's only a matter of time before we catch you in the act."

Peter's eyes met Neal's, a silent warning flashing between them. Neal knew he had to tread carefully. One misstep, and Peter's career would be ruined. But he also knew he couldn't just sit back and let Thompson frame him.

As the days passed, Neal bided his time, gathering evidence and waiting for the perfect moment to strike. It came in the form of a cryptic message from an old associate, hinting at a forgery that had gone wrong. Neal's heart skipped a beat as he realized the implications: this could be the key to clearing his name.

But it came with a price. Thompson was hot on his heels, and he knew he had to act fast. He hatched a plan, one that would require all his cunning and charm. It was reckless, maybe even a little crazy, but it just might work.

Under the guise of a fake meeting with a potential client, Neal convinced Thompson to join him for a drink at a nearby bar. The plan was to use his charm to distract her, to make her let her guard down just enough for him to slip in a crucial piece of evidence.

As they sipped their drinks, Neal launched into a witty monologue, weaving a tale of espionage and intrigue that left Thompson laughing and off guard. It was a delicate balancing act, one that required him to keep his eyes on the prize while maintaining a veneer of innocence.

But just as he was about to make his move, Thompson's phone rang. She answered, her expression darkening as she listened to the person on the other end. Neal's heart sank as he realized he'd been caught off guard.

"What is it, Thompson?" he asked, trying to keep his tone light.

"It seems we've got a new lead," she said, her eyes narrowing. "A witness has come forward claiming to have seen one of our forgers in action. And get this – it's not you, Caffrey. It's... "

Neal's eyes locked onto Thompson's, a spark of hope igniting within him. "Who is it?"

Thompson's smile was a thin, cruel thing. "Someone you least expect."

As the days passed, Neal found himself drawn into a complex web of intrigue. Thompson's lead had yielded a surprising suspect: none other than his old rival, Mozzie. Neal's mind reeled as he tried to process the implications. Mozzie, of all people, had been using his skills for nefarious purposes?

The revelation threw Neal's plan into chaos. He'd been so focused on clearing his own name that he'd ignored the possibility of Mozzie's involvement. But as he delved deeper into the mystery, he began to see the threads that connected them all.

In the end, it was Thompson who provided the crucial clue that cleared Neal's name. A seemingly innocuous comment about her own past had given Neal the opening he needed. He'd used it to his advantage, weaving a narrative that exposed Mozzie's forgery and cleared Neal's name.

As the dust settled, Neal felt a sense of relief wash over him. He'd done it. He'd cleared his name, protected Peter, and even uncovered a shocking truth about his old rival. But more than that, he'd discovered something else – a sense of loyalty and trust that went beyond mere partnership.

Peter's eyes met his, a silent understanding flashing between them. "Thanks, Neal," he said, his voice low and sincere.

Neal smiled, feeling a sense of belonging he'd never thought he'd experience. "Anytime, Pete. We're in this together, now and forever."

The words hung in the air, a promise of a new beginning. And as Neal walked out of the office, Thompson's words echoing in his mind, he knew that he'd finally found his place – not as a master forger, but as a valued member of a team that trusted him with their lives.
